20.24.text:
>> Pete Williams: Hello, hello, Sir Dom.
>> Dom Goucher: Hello, Sir Peter. How is it

25.04.text:
down there in darkest, wherever it is that
you're at for your triathlon because it's

30.29.text:
race week, isn't it?
>> Pete: It is race week. I'm three sleeps

35.30.text:
out from the Ironman, which is very exciting.
Just got back from the masseuse this afternoon

39.70.text:
and a very lazy day tomorrow l I have to
be horizontal on my couch all day according

45.15.text:
to the coach. And then it all sort of happens
from tomorrow night with the Pasta Party and

52.25.text:
the race introduction. And then Saturday,
we take our bike down and take all our gear

58.13.text:
and get that set up. Then at 5:45 a.m. on
Sunday, they gun goes off and the race starts.

64.53.text:
>> Dom: Can I just say that, someone who didn't
know you so well might possibly consider after

72.11.text:
listening to you, that there were some incentives
in this when you started your training. I

77.29.text:
imagine that, possibly, your trainer told
you that at the end of all this effort or

82.34.text:
throughout this effort: one, you get lots
of massages; and then towards the end of it,

87.53.text:
you get to lounge around on the sofa and eat
lots of pasta, and generally hang out with

93.28.text:
your mates. And don't forget, buy lots of
shiny kit.

96.61.text:
>> Pete: I did drop a few hundred dollars
yesterday at the race store. And then surely

103.32.text:
on Monday after they release all the finishers
gear, I'll drop another few hundred dollars

108.05.text:
on race gear. Obviously, in the triathlon
world, you can't really wear Ironman Kit and

114.03.text:
Ironman clothes to training sessions unless
you've actually finished and completed an

118.41.text:
Ironman. So I'm looking forward to being able
to buy up a lot of stuff, and then proudly

122.61.text:
wear that around Melbourne and various training
sessions and races and stuff like that. That

127.07.text:
should be fun.
>> Dom: Any marketing people out there, any

131.44.text:
kind of opportunists marketing people out
there, if you haven't spotted a market yet,

136.82.text:
really, you're not paying attention.
>> Pete: Absolutely, absolutely.

140.62.text:
>> Dom: Good on you, mate. You have stuck
with this. It's like what, 20 weeks training?

145.41.text:
>> Pete: Twenty weeks of training, it's been
very cool. The thing that surprised me the

150.10.text:
most that I've actually talked about with
someone today is l for those you who don't

153.92.text:
know, and it's a bit off-topic, but I used
to race triathlons relatively seriously when

158.55.text:
I was at university in my early 20s. It got
to the point where I came in third in the

164.10.text:
State Championships for my age group.
There were only about five people in my age

168.20.text:
group category, but we won't go there. I made
a promise to myself I'd do an Ironman before

174.47.text:
I'm 30. I'll be 30 in February and here I
am. The crazy thing is, I've been running

180.93.text:
pretty consistently over the last couple of
years. I had a pretty good fitness base, but

185.37.text:
literally 20 weeks ago, I hadn't swam or ridden
a bike more than four times in six years.

192.55.text:
I had very little bike and swim training under
my belt in the last couple of years, and it

199.25.text:
has come back to me amazingly well. So I'm
very, very excited about how that has all

203.63.text:
just come back, and then where I've come from
that perspective in 20 weeks. It's very cool.

209.17.text:
>> Dom: You say that's off-topic, right? But
I'm going to bring it on-topic; I'm going

213.26.text:
to make it relevant because it is. You started
from, not relative unfitness; let's face it,

219.51.text:
you've never been unfit. But, what you have
done is you've been consistent with the training.

226.82.text:
And in 20 weeks, you've gone from, as you
say, somebody who didn't do that much conscious

232.76.text:
exercise and certainly not heavy lifting-kind
of things; and on Sunday morning, you're going

238.87.text:
to do, what is it? What's an Ironman these
days?

242.14.text:
>> Pete: These days... 3.8-kilometer swim,
180-kilometer bike ride and then a 42.2-kilometer

249.18.text:
marathon run at the end. So, I have done marathons.
I've been a pretty fit guy. But in terms of

255.82.text:
race-specific training, I hadn't really done
much. It all comes down to finding someone

261.09.text:
who has done it before, who has done many
Ironmans before, who has coached people through

265.99.text:
the process before, and basically put my faith
in him to a certain extent and just said,

273.96.text:
''Mate, you tell me what to do.
I'm going to be your bitch for 20 weeks,''

277.33.text:
and do exactly what he said. I've only missed
two sessions when I had my calf injury, or

282.28.text:
a bit more of a ligament injury is what you'd
probably call it. But yeah, basically just

287.10.text:
found a process that has worked time and time
again, and just followed it to the letter

291.89.text:
T. I'm here race week and could not feel more
prepared.

297.12.text:
>> Dom: And that's it. That's where I'm getting
to with this. You have stuck at it. You took

304.44.text:
on a coach l or if this was a business thing,
it might be a mentor,

308.75.text:
>> Pete: Yeah, a consultant.
>> Dom: A consultant-type of thing. And you

313.85.text:
put your trust in them that they knew what
they were doing. You found out that they did

316.70.text:
know what they were doing first. You put your
trust in them. And what they told you to do,

320.16.text:
you did it and you did it consistently. Twenty
weeks later, you are, I can't still look at

326.60.text:
these numbers without my eyes wateringu
>> Pete: Eleven hours of pain.

331.90.text:
>> Dom: No pain, no gain; to be a little bit
trite, really.

342.75.text:
>> Pete: True. The goal times, I've got a
couple of goal times. The first goal time

349.36.text:
is to obviously finish, 17-hour cutoff, but
I'll clearly be better than that. My original

354.93.text:
goal time was 12.5 hours. If I do under 12.5,
I'll be very happy with myself. But realistically,

360.56.text:
I reckon I might be able to push 11 hours
if I have a good day. But it's looking pretty

365.65.text:
hot unfortunately.
It's hot and windy which are the two things

368.95.text:
I didn't want. I don't mind the heat so much,
it's just the wind on the bike that will be

373.37.text:
my enemy of the day if it gets too windy.
But we'll deal with it as it comes and just

380.06.text:
push through, cruise it and enjoy the day
as much as I can.

383.52.text:
>> Dom: Cool. Please tell me that you've got
somebody there taking photos?

386.73.text:
>> Pete: Oh, absolutely. There's professional
race photography and the girls are coming

390.15.text:
over as well, so they'll look after me and
take some photos.

392.65.text:
>> Dom: Excellent.
>> Pete: I'll have them up on the blog, on

394.59.text:
Facebook or something like that at some point.
>> Dom: Cool. I'm not exactly looking forward

402.35.text:
to seeing you in spandex, but at least I'm
looking forward... Sorry, I've got the giggles

409.23.text:
now. I think we'd better get serious before
I just lose it.

413.95.text:
>> Pete: Absolutely. So this week, what shall
we be discussing this week?

421.29.text:
>> Dom: I'm out of things to find out myself.
I haven't got a question for you this week.

429.43.text:
I was really hoping that with this downtime,
one of your more thoughtful topics might come

436.17.text:
to me. Have you got something for me?
>> Pete: Yeah, absolutely. It's definitely

438.79.text:
something we can talk about. There's obviously
a big list of future episodes. Something that

444.33.text:
could be worth having bit of a chat about
today is a concept which has primarily been

450.98.text:
popularized by Brian Tracy, who's a fantastic
business writer and author. He gave me a great

459.05.text:
testimonial for my first book, which was very
kind of him.

462.79.text:
It's a concept that he has talked about a
number of times called Zero Based Thinking.

467.96.text:
It's a concept that I really enjoy and try
to apply to a lot of different aspects of

473.68.text:
my life and business. I thought it might be
something we should probably share to people

477.47.text:
who aren't familiar with Zero Based Thinking.
Are you familiar with it at all, Dom?

481.65.text:
>> Dom: You know what, I have never heard
of that.

484.79.text:
>> Pete: Cool. Very exciting then.
>> Dom: Yeah, this is great. This is completely

489.97.text:
new. Awesome.
>> Pete: The premise is around a question.

495.61.text:
The question is basically: knowing what I
know now, would I get into this business/project/job/client/situation

505.46.text:
again? So, knowing what I know now, would
I do what I've just done again? Basically,

514.24.text:
the concept is all about, I guess you'd say
harnessing the benefits of hindsight. That's

519.40.text:
probably a good way of putting it. Because
you want to say, ''Ok, I've obviously been

523.35.text:
through an experience. I've got some knowledge
around this particular area,'' whatever it

527.70.text:
might be.
''Having known what I know now, would I get

531.00.text:
back into this? If I had to wipe the slate
clean, start with a zero base l so I've got

537.15.text:
zero base and zero history, but some hindsight
and knowledge, would I do this again?'' It

543.13.text:
is a really powerful concept when you actually
take the time to sit, digest and actually

550.15.text:
apply it to your business. I first saw this
being applied really well from an investing

557.72.text:
standpoint. And obviously, we speak more about
marketing and business and stuff like that,

561.07.text:
and we'll definitely combine it back to that
in a moment.

564.38.text:
But a really good way of seeing and gaining
some clarity around this Zero Based Thinking

570.12.text:
is from an investment standpoint. Let me say
it a different way. One of my very first stockbrokers

577.33.text:
or advisers told me years and years ago was
basically like, if you consider midnight every

583.48.text:
night you sell your shares and you buy them
back with no brokerage fee l so basically,

589.46.text:
midnight every night, you have to physically
wipe your stock and re-buy it. And if you

595.09.text:
are willing to say, ''Yep, I'm just going
to reinvest in the stocks I currently hold

599.20.text:
today at midnight when I have to repurchase
my stocks, you're good to go.

604.33.text:
Continue holding that share. But, if you would
say, ''Well, actually, hang on, I probably

608.98.text:
wouldn't buy that stock again right now today,''
you should sell that stock. And from a stock

614.42.text:
investing perspective, there are so many people
want to hold that stock even if it's going

619.81.text:
down or if it hasn't moved because they keep
thinking, ''The stock will come back. I'll

626.78.text:
make more money.'' They hold onto the losers
and kill the winners. Everyone has heard that

631.74.text:
sort of analogy with stock market trading,
right?

634.53.text:
>> Dom: Yeah, yeah.
>> Pete: So basically, that's a similar concept

639.29.text:
of Zero Based Thinking. At midnight, you wipe
the slate clean, you wipe you trading account

644.19.text:
clean, you go to a zero base. Would you buy
those stocks again? And so many people actually

649.80.text:
wouldn't, yet they still happen to hold onto
their stocks. It's just a very poor investment

655.01.text:
choice because it means you're chasing your
losers. Having that question answered with

661.17.text:
some clarity helps you to take the emotion
out of the stock trading, which I think is

665.32.text:
really cool.
I heard this again applied in another sort

670.71.text:
of investing space from a friend of mine,
Steve McKnight, who's the No. 1 bestselling

676.65.text:
author in Australia around property investing.
He spoke about this concept in the concept

684.30.text:
of holding real estate as well. There are
so many people who have an investment property

689.85.text:
and they have all this money tied up into
property, all this equity. Now, if you had

695.82.text:
that equity in your bank today, if you had
$100,000 of equity sitting in your bank, would

700.71.text:
you buy that property or would you go and
leverage that money better and buy two or

704.38.text:
three properties at a higher loan ratio or
something like that?

709.38.text:
That concept is, again, a Zero Based Thinking-type
of approach. So many people say, ''I've invested

715.15.text:
$50,000 when I bought this house. It's now
got equity of $200,000, but I'm still holding

721.62.text:
onto that house because I've got a great return
on my $50,000.'' Well, that's not true because

726.01.text:
today, you now you have $200,000 in your investment.
What sort of return is that $200,000 giving

730.61.text:
you today? You have to ignore the $50,000
you put in because that was two years ago.

735.03.text:
That was three years ago.
Today, right now, you've got $200,000 in this

738.60.text:
property. Are you getting a good ROI on that
$200,000 today? Don't do your calculation

743.67.text:
based off the $50,000 you put in, do it off
what you have in equity right now because

747.70.text:
that is your cash that's invested in that
particular asset. Again, it's another way

752.44.text:
to apply Zero Based Thinking to an asset.
In this instance, a property. And then obviously,

758.22.text:
we can go and start applying this to your
business and your marketing because it's really

764.92.text:
important to assess your business on a regular
basis, taking this Zero Based approach.

771.71.text:
>> Dom: That's really cool, I really like
that. And oddly enough, I've never heard of

778.81.text:
it. I've never heard of Zero Based Thinking.
But, it really does reflect a way that I look

785.47.text:
at things from time to time. I do look at
where I am, like where I am with my business

792.95.text:
right now. In fact, this very week, I have
been evaluating my business. Traditionally,

798.50.text:
people do this at the end of the year, at
the end of the month or whenever. But the

802.29.text:
end of the year is a big time for people to
evaluate their business, so it's a really

806.54.text:
good time to have this conversation.
And it is topical for me, without having discussed

811.64.text:
it up front, because I am evaluating my business
and that is exactly a question to ask and

818.26.text:
that I am asking, strangely enough. I've learned
so much, especially in the last year. My business

826.76.text:
has moved from where I started and where I
thought it was going to go, it's gone completely

831.14.text:
over somewhere else. And I'm really pleased
with it, but it's time to decide what I'm

837.79.text:
going to do. And a great way to do that is
this thing, this Zero Based Thinking. Knowing

846.42.text:
what I know now, having the customers that
I've got, looking where it's going to go,

853.96.text:
would I do this again? It is almost, in a
very simplistic way, is it a good business,

858.68.text:
yeah?
>> Pete: Yep, absolutely. And this is like,

861.26.text:
if we talk about it from a website information-marketing
element l and we'll come back to a real-world

868.54.text:
bricks-and-mortar business. But with websites
like Flippa.com, where you can actually relatively

875.17.text:
easily sell a web asset to another online
marketing entrepreneur or whatever the term

881.34.text:
might be this week to describe people who
have a business that only markets online.

887.00.text:
But, if you are running a website or a blog
or an affiliate marketing site, you should

892.97.text:
really assess.
Go spend some time, go onto Flippa, and get

896.70.text:
a bit of an idea of what a website with your
revenue, your traffic numbers is actually

902.68.text:
worth in the marketplace. You can go on there
and see recently sold websites. You can see

908.53.text:
that a site that has 2,000 visitors a week
that is generating $500 a month in revenue,

915.71.text:
or whatever the figures might be, sold for
X, Y and Z. The beautiful thing with online

921.14.text:
businesses, unlike real-world businesses,
is that most online businesses are sold to

927.16.text:
people who are buying it based on the numbers,
not on the passion.

931.09.text:
Whereas in a real-world scenario, if you're
going to go and buy into a franchise or go

935.76.text:
and buy a business from a business broker,
you'll find that people are generally more

940.60.text:
emotionally attached to the type of businesses
they're buying. They're not buying off the

944.03.text:
numbers, they're buying it off the ''I'll
enjoy this because I want a good lifestyle.''

947.52.text:
Whereas, online entrepreneurs are generally
buying stuff on the numbers.

953.21.text:
So the numbers, the ratios, the revenue, the
value of the website that might be in underwater

960.22.text:
kickboxing; if your numbers are relevant but
you're in the cycle or the bike repair niche

968.08.text:
or you're in a niche about how to help massage
therapists get more clients, and your numbers

973.64.text:
are the same or similar, that's how much your
website is worth. That's how much your asset

977.68.text:
is worth right now. So the question you have
to ask yourself is, I have this asset worth

983.00.text:
$5,000; if I have $5,000 cash right now, would
I buy this website? If the answer is no because

993.20.text:
you think there's a better return on your
investment for $5,000, then it's probably

996.81.text:
worth considering, ''Do I sell this?
Do I go and actually sell this website right

1001.55.text:
now and move on to this other opportunity?''
I'm not saying to keep jumping from boat to

1007.68.text:
boat and ship to ship or things like that
regularly because you keep reassessing and

1011.90.text:
flipping stuff. There's a very successful
business model in just buying, selling and

1016.71.text:
renovating stuff or buying, renovating and
selling it. But you have to keep reassessing

1022.27.text:
every six months, every 12 months just, ''What
are my assets that I have in my business and

1027.37.text:
is this the best ROI I can get based on the
value of this asset?''

1030.41.text:
>> Dom: I just want to oversimplify what you
just said about the site and the assets and

1035.74.text:
things like that. Because for the more simplistic
among us in that space that don't have a business

1044.95.text:
that has just the internet as its sole route
to market, what we might have is a large portfolio

1054.61.text:
l going back to your financial example, a
large portfolio of domain names we might have

1060.77.text:
gone through and bought what we thought were
really good domain names years ago and have

1066.72.text:
quite a few of these things sitting around.
>> Pete: Absolutely.

1068.98.text:
>> Dom: Some of them might have websites on
them. But using this Zero Based Thinking,

1074.66.text:
if you go through, let's say, at the end of
the year, you take a couple of weeks off for

1079.15.text:
the nondenominational end-of-year celebration,
and you sit down with your portfolio of domains,

1086.72.text:
and you look through it and go, ''Ok, I bought
that. I thought I was going to do this with

1093.39.text:
it, I didn't. It's going to cost me $10 or
however much to renew that the next time it

1100.68.text:
comes up. Am I going to do it?'' And if you
think about it now rather than when it's due

1106.78.text:
next March, then you can actually have a plan.
And you might think, ''I know I'm not going

1111.66.text:
to do it. And rather than spend that $10,
somebody might actually value that name more

1116.69.text:
than me.'' If there's a site on it and Google
has seen that site, then that has actually

1123.24.text:
got value. Don't devalue that concept. I've
had really big clients with really expensive

1133.53.text:
websites that have cost them in the tens of
thousands of dollars to develop. They're really

1138.91.text:
big companies, but the people who developed
the websites have no concept l and I swear

1144.28.text:
this is true, that just because you put a
website up on the internet, that Google is

1149.94.text:
ever going to see it.
Forget that it doesn't rank very well in the

1156.11.text:
search engines. Anybody that's involved in
online marketing should be aware of this differentiation.

1163.41.text:
Before you can get a good position in the
search results when somebody types in either

1168.03.text:
your company name or the keywords you want
to be found for, Google or any search engines

1173.30.text:
first have to see your website. Those of us
who have been around for while know there

1178.37.text:
are some tricks to getting that to happen.
But if you don't know, then that's valuable

1184.09.text:
because literally, this site had been live
for over a month.

1187.94.text:
They spent multiple tens of thousands of dollars
developing it. It was very incredibly large,

1193.21.text:
well-known international company with a very,
very, very expensive or very valuable product.

1199.44.text:
And in the industry they were in, literally
one day of not selling that product was worth

1204.87.text:
a lot of money. So, one month with that site
and I sat with them. I said, ''Look, let me

1210.51.text:
show. Google doesn't know about your site
and there are ways you can prove this. You

1214.93.text:
can type something into Google and it will
say, LOh, I'm sorry. I have no idea what

1218.16.text:
you are talking about.'''
We're not talking not turning up for your

1222.69.text:
own name, which is almost inexcusable; we
were talking no way it will ever turn up for

1227.32.text:
anything, ever. So that has a value. Even
if you've just got a portfolio of 10, 20 or

1234.69.text:
more domains that have got basic WordPress
on them, it's got value. Even if it's got

1242.57.text:
WordPress on it because some people can't
install WordPress and will pay $100 or more

1247.19.text:
to have WordPress installed. All these things
have value before you even get to, ''I've

1253.91.text:
got a business, I've got traffic, which is
one of those numbers which gives value to

1258.25.text:
something.''
So back to your point, evaluate it. Go back

1263.26.text:
to the beginning and say, ''Look this has
got these things. I can put a value on it.

1268.00.text:
It's got WordPress on it. I might value that
at between $50 and $100 because somebody might

1271.60.text:
have to pay for it.'' The value and the actual
name is difficult, and I wouldn't want to

1278.55.text:
get into that myself. There are some people
out there that just buy and sell the actual

1281.39.text:
domain names and can value them. But this
thing is going to cost you money if you want

1285.47.text:
to renew it, just like your stocks.
Your stocks, you have them and theoretically,

1291.56.text:
you might sell them and buy them back. With
a domain name, you do at least have to renew

1294.91.text:
it every year. And as you involve yourself
more in the running of the site, that's effort

1300.52.text:
to keep it running. So it's a good thing.
Just evaluate your business assets. These

1304.49.text:
domains are business assets, evaluate them.
Be honest with yourself, do one of two things.

1313.47.text:
Or do one thing and do us all a favor. The
first thing is, if you've got any blank domains,

1319.03.text:
please go and install WordPress on them. Put
them on a cheap multi-site hosting package

1323.80.text:
from, oh, I don't know, HostGator is perfect
serviceable hosting company.

1332.09.text:
Get a multi-site hosting package. It's a one-button
job. Put WordPress on all of them and put

1338.07.text:
a page of content on it, because it's worth
more and it's actually doing some work. It

1344.35.text:
might get indexed by Google. Maybe put a little
bit of effort into that. But the minimum is

1348.87.text:
put something on it. Then, sit down and evaluate
it. If you are going to keep it, awesome.

1355.30.text:
If you're not going to keep it, make moves
to sell it somehow through Flippa or one of

1359.82.text:
these marketplaces that Pete has already talked
about.

1362.83.text:
Secondly, if you are going to keep it l and
this is vitally important, put a plan in place.

1369.60.text:
Because if you don't put a plan in place,
then you may as well sell it anyway. Honestly,

1373.74.text:
because you'll be here next year. And you'll
be evaluating it next year. The next year,

1379.14.text:
we'll remind you on the podcast to reevaluate
your domains again and you'll go, ''You know

1384.32.text:
what, I didn't do that.'' Me personally, I'd
rather sell it than feel like crap next year.

1389.27.text:
>> Pete: Yep, absolutely. Speaking of selling
it, we might as well mention our good friend

1394.67.text:
Ed Dale's course, which fits in perfectly,
Dominiche. We'll put a link in the show notes

1402.06.text:
or just preneurmedia.tv/dominiche. We'll put
that on the redirect as well. He's got a great

1412.40.text:
course on buying and selling websites. He's
just released the second version and very

1418.37.text:
much better updated version of the course
as well. I highly recommend it. I bought the

1423.48.text:
first version with my own hard cash and thought
it was amazing, and the second version is

1428.98.text:
just even so much better.
So if you've got some web-based assets and

1433.40.text:
you want to sell them, or you have some cash
and you want to invest and do this Lbuy,

1439.81.text:
renovate and sell' thing, I can highly recommend
Ed's Dominiche. It's awesome. In terms of

1446.59.text:
talking about Zero Based Thinking in other
areas of your business, you should be thinking,

1453.14.text:
you know the clichÚ with your team and your
clients? Knowing what I know now, would I

1460.35.text:
hire this staff member again? So many people
do hold onto the rotten eggs for longer than

1466.59.text:
they can. And again, the clichÚ of Lhire
slow and fire fast' is important. That's definitely

1473.74.text:
worth doing. Also clients, it's ok to fire
some clients.

1479.00.text:
>> Dom: Oh, yes.
>> Pete: Knowing what I know now, would it

1481.49.text:
be ok to take this client on as a client?
In telco business, I have had numerous conversations

1488.00.text:
with clients where I've needed to say, ''Sorry,

Please find someone else to service your phone

there who can offer this service for the phone
systems we sold you and you've got in your

1498.49.text:
business. But we're not the right people to
look after you anymore.'' There's nothing

1502.75.text:
wrong with firing clients.
>> Dom: I totally agree. It's interesting

1509.07.text:
actually. Just to slightly slide sideways
on this one, I recently got an email this

1514.02.text:
last weekend. It's been the Thanksgiving holiday
in America, and it's never been anything I've

1519.33.text:
really been involved in or been aware of because
being very English, it passed me by for many

1526.98.text:
years. But as I've grown my circle of friends
and acquaintances, it's started to come into

1533.22.text:
my awareness. I got an email from one of my
clients, which was a kind of a group email.

1538.43.text:
It was a proper, in the true spirit of Thanksgiving,
it was an email that everybody was asked to

1544.21.text:
talk about what they were thankful for. It
made me think. I sat down and I thought, ''What

1549.88.text:
am I thankful for? And I'm actually thankful
for the fact that this year, all of my clients

1558.05.text:
are fully awesome l all of them, which is
something that not everybody can say. As I've

1568.75.text:
worked through the different jobs I've had
and the different businesses I've been involved

1573.54.text:
inu And you're aware of some of the slightly
more esoteric ones of those.

1579.60.text:
But in the past, I've been involved with some
horrendous clients who just suck your energy,

1587.50.text:
don't appreciate what you do, and don't want
to pay the going rate for your services and

1591.43.text:
all these different things. I wish I could
remember, there was a great passage in a book

1599.37.text:
I read not so long ago. I wish I could remember
which one it was, but we read so many. It

1604.49.text:
was about firing clients. It is a drain on
you and your resources if you keep a client

1613.25.text:
that isn't an LA' client. The more you are
involved with the client, the more it drains

1620.06.text:
you; but it drains your business.
Whoever has to deal with that client, it drains

1622.76.text:
your business. And you can do it, as you've
said. You can do it politely. You can say,

1628.42.text:
''Look, I can't service you. I can't meet
your requirements for cost. I can't be cost-effective

1635.10.text:
for you,'' all these different things. But
yeah, it's another thing to do. And it absolutely

1641.97.text:
is. If you've had that client for six months
or a year, and it has always been a struggle,

1647.12.text:
always been a fight backwards and forwards
with them; then sit down, evaluate it and

1652.41.text:
think, ''If I could kind of talk to myself,''
and that's really what you said, isn't it?

1656.97.text:
''If I could side-look to myself and talk
to myself at the decision pointu

1660.46.text:
>> Pete: If I could go back in time, on that
time machine, in the DeLorean.

1667.73.text:
>> Dom: Yeah, that's it. If could go back,
whisper in my own ear, advise myself, be my

1673.22.text:
own coach, be my own mentor; would I advise

1680.63.text:
Nine times out of ten, you know you'd say
no. I like that. It's good that you've taken

1687.86.text:
this Zero Based Thinking and applied it to
that as well. It is a great concept; I'm scribbling

1693.10.text:
notes furtively about how I'm going to apply
this moving forward.

1696.08.text:
>> Pete: Yep. It comes down to something like
your projects and even your marketing initiatives,

1700.32.text:
the way you get business into the business.
You should always be split testing and re-testing

1706.81.text:
and stuff like that to work out are you getting
better ROIs in other areas and move funds

1712.46.text:
across. That's something that a lot of people
already do. It's sort of a subconscious-type

1717.63.text:
of Zero Based Thinking where they say, ''Oh,
there's a better return of my investment for

1722.48.text:
my marketing dollar, and they'll move that
across.

1724.64.text:
But they want to apply that same concept to
other areas in their business. It just comes

1730.83.text:
down to thinking about your business and all
the elements of your business as little miniature

1735.80.text:
assets, and are you getting the best ROI for
that particular asset? If not, then take the

1743.70.text:
investing approach. At midnight tonight, you
have to basically wipe everything and start

1750.73.text:
again fresh tomorrow. And that includes clients,
the websites you own, the businesses you have,

1758.76.text:
the staff you have, the account you have,

1764.48.text:
that far and ridiculous with it.

1768.83.text:
every night, you have to wipe the slate clean
and start again. What elements of your life

1774.69.text:
and your assets would you want to take with
you tomorrow? And you have to make that mental

1778.87.text:
shift every single night for that Zero Based
Thinking and just apply that. You could almost

1782.69.text:
call it L12:01 a.m. Thinking,' if you wanted
to.

You mentioned it earlier, but you mentioned

they hire for the outsourcing-type tasks.

>> Pete: For those of you who have been playing

1860.64.text:
again, I'll link it through on the show notes,
which you can always get at preneurmedia.tv,

1868.77.text:
the new home of the podcast.
When it comes to outsourcing, I want to build

1874.62.text:
on your point but just put a different context
l again, tying in a previous episode around

1883.75.text:
what you just said, Dom. Two important points
is one, train your staff. One of the best

1889.71.text:
quotes I ever heard when it came to staff
was, LWhat happens if you train them and

1895.80.text:
they leave?' And the response is, LWhat happens
if you don't train them and they stay?' And

1900.16.text:
so many people, when they apply this Zero
Based Thinking to their staff, they're going

1905.72.text:
to go, ''My staff can't do the role I want,
so I'm going to fire them.''

1910.54.text:
But you have to ask yourself a secondary question
in this area, ''Are you firing them because

1916.65.text:
of their personality and their work ethic,
or is it because of their skills?'' If it

1921.75.text:
is because of their skills, you should then
ask a third question, ''Have I given them

1927.85.text:
enough resources so I haven't set them up
to fail?'' What I mean by that is have you

1938.07.text:
actually invested in your asset, and that
asset being a staff member?

1942.05.text:
Have you actually invested in training them
to do the job you need them to do? And if

1947.67.text:
you can answer yourself and say, ''Yes, I
have invested the skills. They just can't

1951.71.text:
do the job because they're incompetent.''
Then by all means, fire them. But if it's

1955.40.text:
because you haven't given them the skills
and armed them with the ammunition they need,

1960.21.text:
then you might have to assess, is this Zero
Based Thinking the right way to go about it?

1965.79.text:
>> Dom: Wow, that is actually a really important

and time again, we come back to this when

If you didn't, first of all, go through the

to do, then you set them up to fail. If you
just hired themu

you've probably corresponded with Flo who's

sort of stuff, and now she is diving off the

and swimming. But, that was after she learned

You can't expect that from Day One.

2161.08.text:
>> Dom: No. And this is the most common mistake,
it doesn't matter who you hire, it doesn't

2167.75.text:
matter what they say on their CV, you can

l back to your point.

>> Dom: So many people are afraid, ''Oh, if

phrase, what happens if you don't?

2236.24.text:
don't get the job done properly. You cannot
expect anybodyu In the same vein as that,

2245.42.text:
probably in the same sentence actually was,
if you went to work, you started a job and

you walked in the front door, and somebody

kind of another kind of Zero Based Thinking.
If somebody dumped that request on you, could

2263.90.text:
you do it with the information that's provided
in the context?

2268.38.text:
If you had no training, could you do it? I
regularly get requests from my clients. And

2275.57.text:
I send emails straight back and say, ''I'm

2281.87.text:
You're missing very important points like
what website you want me to work on.'' For

example, people who write instructions for

they miss out. And that's another one of those

2299.94.text:
get really angry at anybody: outsourcers,

whatever.
If you weren't clear, yes, it would help if

2308.37.text:
they maybe teased more information out of

2313.96.text:
that in a way is a skill that's learned and

make sure you have given whatever it was a

>> Dom: Don't go crazy with an axe, chopping

things out; make sure you're looking at what

this website and this client of mine with

sure you're looking at what you think you're

is it you?

I think we should wrap today's episode up

by giving everyone the opportunity to take

would you actually buy that asset again today?

Learn how to sell it at the highest price

project. So, just work out how you can apply

in the business right now? So, there you go,
